text:
Getting all the necessary software installed, configured, and playing nicely together is half the battle when first adopting an open source, reproducable scientific workflow. These steps have become increasingly easier over the years and we are here to help you if you hit a hurdle üòÑ
Welcome to ESS 330, Quantitative Reasoning for Ecosystem Science! In this course, we‚Äôll be using R and RStudio for data organization, manipulation, analysis, and visualization. You‚Äôll become more familiar with both tools throughout the course.
It‚Äôs highly recommended to install these tools on your own laptop for convenience and the following step-by-step guide will walk you through installing R and RStudio on your computer, as well as introducing a few essential tools we‚Äôll use throughout the quarter. If you encounter any issues during the process, don‚Äôt hesitate to contact me or a teaching assistant for assistance!

title: Daily Exercise 01
text:
Installing Package
R comes loaded with many base packages and tools. There are also many additional tools that will make your life easier. Throughout this class, we‚Äôll use packages that exist in the aggregate tidyverse package.

Tidyverse
The tidyverse contains a collection of very useful packages that play nicely together for data exploration, manipulation, wrangling and visualization (among other things). Packages can be installed from CRAN (Comprehensive R Archive Network) using the following pattern which should be typed in the console (yellow box):

install.packages("tidyverse")

After you press ‚ÄòEnter,‚Äô you should see a whole bunch of text streaming across the Console Window. This is a good sign and is simply logging what‚Äôs being downloaded/installed. This process can go on for a few minutes (the tidyverse has a lot of different components). You will know it‚Äôs done when the active cursor shows up again waiting for your next command.
Once it‚Äôs installed, you can ensure that everything worked by loading/attaching the tidyverse using the library call:

library(tidyverse)

title: Ecosystem Science and Sustainability 330
text:
Welcome!
Welcome to Ecosystem Science and Sustainability 330: Quantitative Reasoning for Ecosystem Science! This course is your entery point to understanding data science tools and techniques essential for solving today‚Äôs most pressing environmental challenges. We aim to equip students with the essential quantitative tools and reasoning skills needed to address complex challenges in ecosystem science. It emphasizes the integration of open-source technologies, statistical methods, spatial data analysis, and machine learning to foster reproducible, data-driven insights.

title: Ecosystem Science and Sustainability 330
text:
Who This Class is For
This course is ideal for students in ecosystem science, sustainability, and related disciplines who want to enhance their data science skills. Whether you‚Äôre new to coding or looking to expand your expertise, ESS 330 provides the tools to address critical environmental challenges with data-driven insights. By the end of this course, students will have the skills (and confidence to continue learning) to tackle a wide range of applied and theoretical questions, including:

How can I efficiently organize, store, and share data for a research project?
How do I set up a reproducible workflow using R, Git, and GitHub?
How do I clean, merge, and visualize messy datasets from different sources?
What statistical methods should I use to test my hypotheses?
How can I identify patterns and relationships in environmental datasets?
How can I predict ecosystem changes using regression and machine learning models?
How do I design, train, and evaluate models to ensure reliable predictions?
How can I analyze and forecast environmental trends using time-series data?
How do I process and analyze spatial data to answer location-based questions?
How can I visualize and interpret geospatial trends in ecosystem variables?
How can GIS tools be integrated into larger data science workflows?

title: Ecosystem Science and Sustainability 330
text:
Careers
Graduates of this course will be equipped to pursue careers as geospatial analysts, ecological modelers, data scientists, hydrologists, or climate scientists. You‚Äôll be prepared to tackle pressing environmental challenges in academia, government, industry, or NGOs, making data-driven decisions to shape the future of ecosystem science and sustainability.

title: Ecosystem Science and Sustainability 330
text:
About this course
Quantitative reasoning involves analyzing, interpreting, and solving problems using numerical and logical reasoning. This course equips students with essential data science and quantitative skills, focusing on applying these methods to problems in ecosystem science and sustainability.
Students will engage in practical data-driven approaches through lectures, live coding demonstrations, discussions, and hands-on lab sessions. The course emphasizes the use of open-source technologies (R, Quarto), statistical methods, geospatial data analysis, and machine learning within reproducible workflows.
By the end of this course, students will:

Assess ecosystem science challenges using quantitative tools.

Apply data-driven methods to real-world sustainability issues.

Use these skills in scientific research, decision-making, and environmental data analysis.

Prerequisites: MATH 155/160; STAT 301/307/315; ESS 211 or LIFE 320
Credits: 3
Course Website: https://github.com/mikejohnson51/csu-ess-330

title: Ecosystem Science and Sustainability 330
text:
Course Units
An approximate weekly schedule is available on the course home page. While it is subject to change, we will be guided by four primary units:

Open Science and Tools (Weeks 1-3)

Introduction to reproducible workflows and software (R, Rmd, Git)
Learning efficient interaction with computers whether you love them or hate them

Working with Data (Weeks 4-7)

Cleaning, refining, and analyzing messy data sets
Techniques for effective data interpretation

Modeling (Weeks 8-12)

Statistical, predictive, and classification models to solve ecosystem-related problems
Pull the current back on ‚ÄúMachine Learning‚Äù
Understand that ‚Äúall‚Äù problems are either prediction or classification

Geospatial Data (Weeks 13-16)

Applying spatial information to data analysis and problem-solving

title: Ecosystem Science and Sustainability 330
text:
Components

Daily Exercises (20%)
Daily coding or reading assignments will conclude each class. These short assignments (30 minutes) are graded pass/fail and are intended to reinforce the concepts learned during lectures. Students are required to complete 25 out of 29 assignments, with the remaining 4 serving as extra credit opportunities.


Lab Activities (10%)
Each weeks lab will have an associated activity, completed in class, that helps solidify topics from lecture. Students are required to complete 12 out of 13 activities, with the remaining 1 serving as extra credit opportunities.


Labs (50%)
Approximately 9 hands-on labs will provide applied learning experiences, focusing on solving real-world problems through data analysis. Lab assignments will be released on Sundays and are due the designated Sunday at 11:59 PM. While some labs only last 1 weeks, others will take more.


Final project (20%)
Students will design and choose a final project to demonstrate their quantitative reasoning skills, mixing ideas from lectures and labs to answer a question of interest to them. Final projects will be presented in the final lab section - lightning talk style.


Extra Credit Opportunities (10%)

title: Ecosystem Science and Sustainability 330

Course Material

All readings and resources are free and avialable online
It is highly encouraged that you do all work on you own laptop. You‚Äôll need a machine with a full OS (not Chromebook) to install the software and process the data we‚Äôll be working with. If this is not possible for you, please work with me or your TA to find a good solution.
This class borrows from the R community and the data science world at large - particualry from UCSB. It seeks to provide a curreated set of the best material along with careful guidance through it. If someone has made exceptional resources, we want to share that with you rather then reinvnet the wheel (a core tenet of data science at large - borrow, share, contirbute)

title: Ecosystem Science and Sustainability 330
text:
How to Approach this course:
The material covered in the course aims to provide continuity and it is cumulative. You will be learning a set of practical skills meaning that techniques we learn in early weeks will be necessary for understanding things that come later. It also means that regular practice will help you a lot. So, this is not a ‚ÄúTopic of the week‚Äù course where you can tune out for a few weeks while expecting to be able to easily drop back in later. The material we cover each week will not be overwhelming. If you participate during class and keep up with the weekly assignments you‚Äôll be in a very strong position to do well in the class. If you don‚Äôt, it‚Äôll be harder than you expected.

title: Ecosystem Science and Sustainability 330
text:
My promise
This course is designed to build practical, cumulative skills that are essential for success in environmental data science. Each week‚Äôs content builds on what you‚Äôve learned before, so regular participation and consistent practice are key. Labs and daily assignments will reinforce foundational concepts, and early engagement will set you up for long-term success.
By committing to the work and completing the daily assignments, you‚Äôll gain valuable skills and perform well. Jaque, Alan, and I will be here to support you throughout the semester, ready to help you navigate any challenges.
This course may present a steep learning curve, but with persistence and effort, you‚Äôll find the support you need to succeed. Stick with the course, stay engaged, and do the work‚Äîespecially the daily assignments‚Äîand you‚Äôll not only earn a good grade, but also build the skills to excel as an environmental data scientist.
This approach has proven effective for many past students, including those I‚Äôve hired at Lynker and NOAA. While some students may choose to withdraw, I‚Äôve never had a student who stuck with the course and put in the effort finish with a grade lower than a B.
So, please don‚Äôt let the possibility of a challenging start be a reason to hold back!

title: Ecosystem Science and Sustainability 330
text:
Software
In this course we will use R which is an open source programming environment. You will interact with R through the RStudio IDE. Your projects and code will be turned into through GitHub as Quarto reports. Through the course you will build an online portfolio that can be taken with you latter on. If you haven‚Äôt used these tools before, don‚Äôt worry - we will get up and running with them during the first week.
